metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Rust Vectors
Vectors
A vector is a resizable array. Unlike regular arrays, vectors can grow or shrink in size.
content.html: A vector is a resizable array. Unlike regular arrays, vectors can grow or shrink in size.

content.text: Creating a Vector
To create a vector, use the vec! macro:
content.html: To create a vector, use the vec! macro:

content.code_html: let fruits = vec!["apple", "banana", "orange"];

content.text: This creates a vector with three string elements.
content.html: This creates a vector with three string elements.

content.text: Access Vector Elements
You can access values in a vector using index numbers (just like arrays):
content.html: You can access values in a vector using index numbers (just like arrays):

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let fruits = vec!["apple", "banana", "orange"];
println!("First fruit: {}", fruits[0]);

content.code:
let fruits = vec!["apple", "banana", "orange"];
println!("First fruit: {}", fruits[0]);

syntax_highlighting.text:
let fruits = vec!["apple", "banana", "orange"];
println!("First fruit: {}", fruits[0]);

content.code_html:
let fruits = vec!["apple", "banana", "orange"];
println!("First fruit: {}", fruits[0]);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let fruits = vec!["apple", "banana", "orange"];
println!("First fruit: {}", fruits[0]);

content.text: Change Vector Values
To change a value in the vector, refer to the index number and assign a new value.
content.html: To change a value in the vector, refer to the index number and assign a new value.

content.text: Remember to make the vector mutable (using the mut keyword):
content.html: Remember to make the vector mutable (using the mut keyword):

content.code_html:
let mut fruits = vec!["apple", "banana", "orange"];
fruits[0] = "grape";
println!("New first fruit: {}", fruits[0]);

content.text: Add Elements to a Vector
You can add a new element to the end of a vector using the push() method:
content.html: You can add a new element to the end of a vector using the push() method:

content.code_html:
let mut fruits = vec!["apple", "banana"];
fruits.push("cherry");
println!("{:?}", fruits); // ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]

content.text: Remove Elements from a Vector
To remove the last element from a vector, use pop() :
content.html: To remove the last element from a vector, use pop():

content.code_html:
let mut fruits = vec!["apple", "banana", "cherry"];
fruits.pop();
println!("{:?}", fruits); // ["apple", "banana"]

content.text: Add or Remove Elements at a Specified Index
Rust vectors are designed to grow and shrink at the end , but you can also add or remove elements at the beginning or at a specified index .
content.html: Rust vectors are designed to grow and shrink at the end, but you can also add or remove elements at the beginning or at a specified index.

content.text: Use insert() to add an item at a specified index:
content.html: Use insert() to add an item at a specified index:

content.code_html:
let mut fruits = vec!["banana", "orange"];
fruits.insert(0, "apple");
println!("{:?}", fruits); // ["apple", "banana", "orange"]

let mut fruits = vec!["banana", "orange"];
fruits.insert(1, "apple");
println!("{:?}", fruits); // ["banana", "apple", "orange"]

content.text: Remove the First Item
Use remove() to remove an element from a specified index:
content.html: Use remove() to remove an element from a specified index:

content.code_html:
let mut fruits = vec!["apple", "banana", "orange"];
fruits.remove(0);
println!("{:?}", fruits); // ["banana", "orange"]

content.text: Note: Adding or removing elements from the beginning is slower than at the end, because all the other elements have to shift positions.
content.html: Note: Adding or removing elements from the beginning is slower than at the end, because all the other elements have to shift positions.

content.text: Vector Length
You can find out how many elements there are in a vector using the .len() method:
content.html: You can find out how many elements there are in a vector using the .len() method:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let fruits = vec!["apple", "banana", "cherry"];
println!("There are {} fruits.", fruits.len());

content.code:
let fruits = vec!["apple", "banana", "cherry"];
println!("There are {} fruits.", fruits.len());

syntax_highlighting.text:
let fruits = vec!["apple", "banana", "cherry"];
println!("There are {} fruits.", fruits.len());

content.code_html:
let fruits = vec!["apple", "banana", "cherry"];
println!("There are {} fruits.", fruits.len());

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let fruits = vec!["apple", "banana", "cherry"];
println!("There are {} fruits.", fruits.len());

content.text: Loop Through a Vector
Just like arrays, you can use a for loop to go through all the values in a vector:
content.html: Just like arrays, you can use a for loop to go through all the values in a vector:

content.code_html:
let fruits = vec!["apple", "banana", "orange"];
for fruit in &fruits {
  println!("I like {}.", fruit);
}

content.text: Note: Use &fruits to borrow the vector instead of moving it.
content.html: Note: Use &fruits to borrow the vector instead of moving it.

content.text: In Rust, borrowing means using a reference to a value instead of taking ownership of it. When you loop through a vector without & , the values are moved out, and you can no longer use the vector. But when you borrow the vector using & , you can still use it later in your program.
content.html: In Rust, borrowing means using a reference to a value instead of taking ownership of it. When you loop through a vector without &, the values are moved out, and you can no longer use the vector. But when you borrow the vector using &, you can still use it later in your program.

content.text: You can learn more about ownership in our chapters on Ownership and Borrowing and References .
content.html: You can learn more about ownership in our chapters on Ownership and Borrowing and References.
